item.title: Photography
item.description: Sometimes I take pictures. This project is about the pictures I take. Sometimes, they are pictures of cats.

item.title: About
item.description: ![The Bickel’s](“img/family”) Who I Am Hello! My name is Eric Bickel - and independent consultant looking to use data to help clients solve problems. Most of this site houses personal analysis and write-ups on interesting tools and datasets that I’ve come across while nerding out - but I hope that as a portfolio, they are interesting and fun to read while also showcasing some of what I can help clients out with!

item.title: Using ANN To Predict Euthanasia in LMAS Intake
item.description: Overview and Introduction Driven by the desire to do something as fun and interesting as this post by the folks at Decision Science, I decided to dust off some previous work done on Louisville Metro Animal Services Animal [‚ÄúLMAS‚Äù] Intake and Outcome data (you can get it here). The problems are sort of the same at the core - while the linked work focuses on customer churn, this analysis will focus on what information tends to predict a given animal will be euthanized at LMAS using Artificial Neural Networks (‚ÄúANN‚Äù).

item.title: Using Data to Reduce Euthanasia Rates
item.description: Overview and Introduction The bulk of this work - including methodology and data sources (and fun visuals!) - currently sits in the blog section if you want to read through it. This write-up provides only a quick synopsis of the work covered there, and any learnings. There were a number of key findings in the analysis that could be of use.

item.title: Embedding d3 Visuals in Rmarkdown
item.description: Background The purpose of this tutorial is to walk through using d3.js within an Rmd document that is then rendered as an HTML page with a Hugo static site generator. That was probably the most technical sentence of this entire write-up, so let‚Äôs all breath a sigh of relief now that we‚Äôre through with it. This is a quick release, so I‚Äôm not going to go into much detail about the process to get the data and what it fully represents just yet - I‚Äôm saving that for a deeper post with a ‚Äútbd‚Äù release date at this point.

item.title: Knitting to Output with Rmarkdown
item.description: Tutorial‚Äôs purpose Manipulating data and building visuals is the bread and butter of the R language - but what can get lost in the fold is the ability to easily and quickly push analysis out for folks to see. Using knitr and rmarkdown makes that significantly easier, and exists at the press of a button. In this tutorial, we‚Äôre going to press those buttons. What are the packages? There are a ton of ways to get information from R out into the world - ranging from static Word or PDF documents all the way to interactive web applications.

item.title: Into the Tidyverse
item.description: Today‚Äôs purpose To walk through the tidyverse and become familiar with the functions that it provides the user and how it can make your life so much better to use. What the heck even is a tidyverse? tidyverse is a collection of R packages providing an all-inclusive resource for data science (well, almost). When you library(tidyverse) the following packages are loaded up as dependencies: Package Description ggplot2 Graphics-building package based on The Grammar of Graphics mapping aesthetics to data visually tibble Wrapper on traditional dataframes allowing for better printing and viewing data tidyr Package to easily and quickly get your data into a rectangular format (if not already in one) readr Super fast package for reading in rectangular data (like csv, tsv, and fwf) purrr A set of tools for working with functions and vectors for functional programming techniques dplyr Quickly and efficiently manipulate data with a Grammar of Manipulation (just made that up) Within each of these there are a handful of other dependencies - not all of which I am going to talk through.

item.title: Scraping Whiskey Reviews Using Scrapy
item.description: Background This is a working document to help understand the first stage of this project - the data grab. It is also a helpful learning tool for myself, as this is the first real spider that I’ve created to pull data from a website. Setup The initial setup is quick, simply cd into the directory that you want to work in and run - scrapy startproject whiskey_reviews Easy enough.

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. You can embed an R code chunk like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.98 ## 3rd Qu.
